image.altText: A group of volunteers surrounded by stranded pilot whales

items.synopsis: Authorities are urging the public to stay clear as they work to save the lives of the remaining 46 pilot whales stranded on Cheynes Beach.

title.children: 'Devastating': 51 whales dead on WA beach as difficult rescue effort continues

image.altText: A bald man in black tshirt and woman with long dark hair and grey jumper work in a drycleaning facility surrounded by machinery.

items.synopsis: Inflation has slowed down again, with consumer prices up 6 per cent over the year to June, below most economists' forecasts and reducing the chance of an RBA rate rise next week.

title.children: Inflation falls faster than expected. Has the Reserve Bank already increased interest rates too far?

image.altText: Gordi Kirkbank-Ellis side-by-side with his brain scan

items.synopsis: The effect of head knocks over Gordi Kirkbank-Ellis's decades-long sporting career isn’t immediately obvious. That is, until you see what’s happening to his brain.

title.children: From the age of 4, Gordi played contact sports. See how it has impacted his brain

image.altText: fresh fruit in aisles of a grocery shop

items.synopsis: Consumer inflation for the June quarter falls more than expected by economists, while the IMF warns of persistent challenges for the global economy. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Inflation falls to 6 per cent as interest rate hikes dampen demand, ASX surges, IMF warns of economic challenges

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Council of Trade Unions wants the Reserve Bank to put interest rate increases on hold because of the drop in inflation. They note real wages are not keeping up with the cost of living and household budgets remain under pressure. Over the year, rents increased by 6.7 per cent, utilities rose nearly 14 per cent, and bread, milk and cheese prices have all soared. Here's ACTU assistant secretary Joseph Mitchell: “Today’s figures show that family budgets are still under unprecedented pressures with everyday items are eating more out of workers hard earned wages." "Corporate profits are still on the rise with data showing Australia had the third highest growth in profits  in the OECD between 2019 and 2023, indicating big business is price gouging workers through this  crisis." "The RBA should note this fall in inflation and not inflict any more pain on pockets of hard-working  Australians who are just trying to get on with everyday life, yet are being punished for a crisis they  played no part in."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ACTU calls for rate hike pause

children.content: The Australian Council of Trade Unions wants the Reserve Bank to put interest rate increases on hold because of the drop in inflation.
They note real wages are not keeping up with the cost of living and household budgets remain under
pressure.
Over the year, rents increased by 6.7 per cent, utilities rose nearly 14 per cent, and bread, milk and cheese prices have all soared.
Here's ACTU assistant secretary Joseph Mitchell:
“Today’s figures show that family budgets are still under unprecedented pressures with everyday items are eating more out of workers hard earned wages."

"Corporate profits are still on the rise with data showing Australia had the third highest growth in profits  in the OECD between 2019 and 2023, indicating big business is price gouging workers through this  crisis."

"The RBA should note this fall in inflation and not inflict any more pain on pockets of hard-working  Australians who are just trying to get on with everyday life, yet are being punished for a crisis they  played no part in."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As Gareth, and the ABS, correctly point out, on an annual basis services inflation has picked up and is running at the highest level since the GST. But if you dive into the bureau's excel spreadsheets, you find the quarterly picture is quite different. Goods prices (+0.9%) actually increased by more in the June quarter compared to March than services prices (+0.8%). Moreover, the quarterly increase in services prices was the lowest in a year, falling dramatically from a peak of 2.1% in December — when travel providers jacked up prices for summer holidays. The main reason the annual reading is so high is that lower figures from the COVID period have now all dropped out of the annual data, which is dragged up by big services prices rises in the September (+1.6%), December (+2.1%) and March (+1.7%) quarters. The rise of 0.8% in the three months to June is less than half that seen in the previous quarter so, on that basis, services inflation is actually decelerating rather sharply. It must be noted, though, that these quarterly figures are NOT seasonally adjusted, and a quick look back through recent data hints that June is probably the weakest quarter for services price rises on average.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Quarterly data paints a slightly different picture on services inflation

children.content: As Gareth, and the ABS, correctly point out, on an annual basis services inflation has picked up and is running at the highest level since the GST.
But if you dive into the bureau's excel spreadsheets, you find the quarterly picture is quite different.
Goods prices (+0.9%) actually increased by more in the June quarter compared to March than services prices (+0.8%).
Moreover,
the quarterly increase in services prices was the lowest in a year
, falling dramatically from a peak of 2.1% in December — when travel providers jacked up prices for summer holidays.
The main reason the annual reading is so high is that lower figures from the COVID period have now all dropped out of the annual data, which is dragged up by
big services prices rises in the September (+1.6%), December (+2.1%) and March (+1.7%) quarters
The rise of 0.8% in the three months to June is less than half that seen in the previous quarter so, on that basis,
services inflation is actually
decelerating
rather sharply
It must be noted, though, that these quarterly figures are
NOT seasonally adjusted
, and a quick look back through recent data hints that
June is probably the weakest quarter for services price rises
on average.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reaction to the fall in inflation is coming thick and fast. Not surprisingly, Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers has welcomed the figures. "Today’s figures from the ABS show the price pressures in our economy continue to moderate in welcome ways," he says. "It’s pleasing that inflation is moderating, and while we would prefer it moderate more quickly to ease pressure on household budgets, we are making progress. " "Inflation both here and around the world is remaining higher than we’d like for longer than we'd like, but it’s tracking downwards in the right direction." And Mr Chalmers has pointed to the government's cost of living relief measures in the budget, which include rent and energy bill assistance. "The Government’s number one priority is getting on top of the inflation challenge and providing cost-of-living relief for Australians families." "The cost-of-living relief policies are directly reducing price pressures in the economy by three quarters of a percentage point this financial year. " The budget surplus for the 2022-23 is expected to come in at around $20 billion - nearly five times the $4.2 billion predicted in May's budget. However, the Treasurer has so far ruled out additional cost of living relief measures.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer says making progress on inflation

children.content: Reaction to the fall in inflation is coming thick and fast.
Not surprisingly, Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers has welcomed the figures.
"Today’s figures from the ABS show the price pressures in our economy continue to moderate in welcome ways," he says.
"It’s pleasing that inflation is moderating, and while we would prefer it moderate more quickly to ease pressure on household budgets, we are making progress. "
"Inflation both here and around the world is remaining higher than we’d like for longer than we'd like, but it’s tracking downwards in the right direction."
And Mr Chalmers has pointed to the government's cost of living relief measures in the budget, which include rent and energy bill assistance.
"The Government’s number one priority is getting on top of the inflation challenge and providing cost-of-living relief for Australians families."
"The cost-of-living relief policies are directly reducing price pressures in the economy by three quarters of a percentage point this financial year. "
The budget surplus for the 2022-23 is expected to come in at around $20 billion - nearly five times the $4.2 billion predicted in May's budget.
However, the Treasurer has so far ruled out additional cost of living relief measures.
